page.title: 13Landscape and Architecture
page.content: The landscape is one of rolling hills, mainly treeless, apart from a few areas of planted coniferous forest. The buildings are varied and interesting despite the rigid street pattern evolved from the setting out of Feus at the end of the 18th century. No two buildings are alike apart from the houses in the small council development to the northwest of the main street. The reasons for this variety are two- fold. Firstly the materials of construction are mainly slate for roofs, the origins of which vary and an indigenous pinky-red sandstone from a nearby quarry in the Ochil Hills. The bed of the stone was relatively shallow, producing stones which were often laid at right angles to their natural bed leading to erosion by
